intro: Tridactyle tridentata, commonly known as the three-toothed spurge, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of southern Africa. It belongs to the family Euphorbiaceae, which includes many species with latex-producing characteristics. The plant is notable for its simple, opposite leaves and small, inconspicuous flowers clustered in cyathia, typical of the Euphorbiaceae family. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or sandy habitats. Due to its drought tolerance, it is sometimes used in xeriscaping and as a ornamental plant in dry climates.
